item.title: Venezuela Mourns the Dozens Who Died in U.S. Operation
item.description: For all Venezuelans, the nighttime raid opened a period of deep uncertainty. For the families of those killed, it meant the grim task of burying their relatives.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Friends and family at the burial of Rosa Elena González, 80, who was killed during the U.S. raid to capture Venezuela’s president, Nicolás Maduro.

item.title: Once Again, a Newfoundland Town Rescues Stranded Passengers
item.description: After 9/11, Gander took in thousands of people whose flights were diverted. History repeated on a smaller scale this week.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: The airport in Gander, Newfoundland, where three flights were diverted this week for bad weather, stranding travelers.

item.title: U.S. Navy Is Chasing Several Oil Tankers in the Atlantic
item.description: A mass departure by sanctioned tankers, some switching to Russian flags, has triggered a fresh effort by the United States to pursue Venezuelan oil shipments at sea.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert, Riley Mellen and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: An image from video released by the U.S. military purporting to show the seizure of the oil tanker M Sophia in the Caribbean on Wednesday.

item.title: Rocío San Miguel, Venezuelan Political Prisoner, Was Among Those Released
item.description: Ms. San Miguel’s arrest in 2024 raised fears that Venezuela had entered a new era of repression.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Oscar Del Pozo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators demanding the release of Rocío San Miguel, one of Venezuela’s most prominent political prisoners, at a rally held in Madrid, last year.

item.title: Russian Propaganda Ramps Up After U.S. Raid in Venezuela
item.description: A network of websites known as “Portal Kombat” is spreading messages about U.S. military hardware, according to tracking firms.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Red Square in Moscow. Russia and Venezuela have had a close diplomatic relationship, and Moscow is keen to retain those ties.

item.title: Fact-Checking Trump’s Justifications for the Venezuela Operation
item.description: The president has repeatedly tied Venezuela to drug overdose deaths, claimed the Maduro regime sent an influx of criminal migrants and accused the country of stealing American oil.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump at a news conference on Saturday at Mar-a-Lago.

item.title: Macron tells ambassadors that the world has become ‘unhinged.’
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France in Paris on Thursday. He told a group of global ambassadors that rules around the world had been discarded.

item.title: Venezuela Leaders Free Political Prisoners in a Sign of Possible Change
item.description: The interim government released some prisoners under pressure from the Trump administration, even as it continued arrests and crackdowns elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Emma Bubola, Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Atali Cabrejo waits for the release of her son, Juan Jose Freites, outside El Helicoide prison in Caracas, Venezuela, on Thursday.

item.title: Senate Advances Measure to Curb Trump’s Use of Force in Venezuela
item.description: A handful of Republicans joined Democrats to allow the measure to move forward, reflecting concerns in both parties about the administration’s strategy.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison and Megan Mineiro
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: “Make no mistake: Bombing another nation’s capital and removing their president is an act of war, plain and simple,” Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, said before the vote.

item.title: Thomas Massie Thinks Trump and Republicans Are ‘Gaslighting’ on Venezuela
item.description: Representative Thomas Massie, a rare Republican critic of President Trump’s military intervention, explained his concerns in an interview with The New York Times.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Thomas Massie, Republican of Kentucky, in November. In an interview on Wednesday, he slammed “a flimsy constitutional argument” for the United States’ seizure and prosecution of Venezuela’s leader.

item.title: Rubio Says He’ll Discuss Greenland With Danish Officials Next Week
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio told reporters he would speak with the officials after days of mounting threats from the Trump administration to take Greenland, a semiautonomous Danish territory.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio said he would meet with Danish officials next week to discuss the future of Greenland.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Robert Jimison

item.title: Tips for Caribbean Vacations and Travel Insurance After Venezuela Operation
item.description: The recent military operation in Venezuela disrupted vacations to popular destinations. Here are tips for buying travel insurance and protecting your trip.
item.dc:creator: Gabe Castro-Root
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Passengers were stranded at Luis Muñoz Marín International Airport near San Juan, P.R., last weekend after the F.A.A. closed some airspace to U.S. civilian aircraft.

item.title: Colombia’s President Feared a U.S. Attack. Then Trump Called.
item.description: The conversation appeared to defuse a crisis that erupted after President Trump said military action against Colombia “sounds good.” President Gustavo Petro spoke to The New York Times just before the call.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal, Max Bearak and Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Nathalia Angarita for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Gustavo Petro of Colombia during an interview with The New York Times in Cartagena on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump Says U.S. Oversight of Venezuela Could Last for Years
item.description: In a wide-ranging interview with The New York Times on Wednesday, President Trump said “only time will tell” when it comes to how long the United States aims to control the country.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Tyler Pager, Katie Rogers and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: President Trump in the Oval Office with Vice President JD Vance and Secretary of State Marco Rubio on Wednesday.

item.title: Most Venezuelans Struggle to Pay for Food, Poll Shows
item.description: A new Gallup survey found that more than half of Venezuelans reported struggling to afford food last year, with economic hardship reaching even the wealthy.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:description: At a street market in Caracas, the capital of Venezuela, in October.

item.title: Trump and Colombian President Speak by Phone Amid Escalating Tensions
item.description: The American president said a White House visit with Gustavo Petro was being arranged by the secretary of state.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump returning to the White House on Sunday. Mr. Trump said he was looking forward to a meeting with Colombia’s president at the White House soon.

item.title: What Are ‘Ghost Fleet’ Ships?
item.description: Also known as “dark fleet” or “shadow fleet” ships, the vessels use murky tactics to transport oil in violation of sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: An image from video footage released by the U.S. military purporting to show the seizure of the oil tanker M Sophia in the Caribbean Sea on Wednesday.

item.title: Amid heavy security, a tentative return of street life in Caracas.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Vendors and shoppers at a street market in the Petare neighborhood of Caracas, Venezuela, on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S., Cementing Control on Venezuelan Oil, Seizes Russian-Flagged Tanker
item.description: The vessel was one of two taken into American custody as the Trump administration said it was executing a “deal to take all the oil.”
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Nehamas, Eric Schmitt, Julian E. Barnes and Michael Levenson
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The oil tanker Marinera, formerly known as Bella 1, at sea in the Singapore Strait last year.

item.title: During Maduro Raid in Venezuela, a Close Call for Helicopters and Trump’s Plan
item.description: As a damaged U.S. helicopter struggled to stay aloft over Venezuela’s capital, the success of the entire operation hung in the balance.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Greg Jaffe
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Miguel J. Rodriguez Carrillo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Senate Republicans Push Back on Trump’s Aspirations to Seize Greenland
item.description: Opposition was stacking up to the United States buying the semiautonomous island or taking it by force.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, background, looking toward Senator Tim Kaine, Democrat of Virginia, at the Capitol on Wednesday.

item.title: Lawmakers Are Split After Classified Briefings on Venezuela
item.description: Republicans praised what they characterized as a narrow and well-executed plan, while Democrats expressed alarm, warning that the mission was vaguely defined.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison and Megan Mineiro
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio speaking at the Capitol on Wednesday after a Senate briefing on operations in Venezuela.

item.title: How The Times Is Drawing on Over a Century of Reporting in Venezuela
item.description: The New York Times has been on the ground in the country since at least the 1880s, through celebration, suffering and political turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario/Corbis Saba, for The New York Times
item.media:description: The New York Times has made on-the-ground reporting in Venezuela a priority for more than a century. Above, a demonstration against Hugo Chávez in 2002.

item.title: Oil Firms Say Venezuela Owes Them Billions Over Earlier Investments
item.description: Companies like Exxon Mobil and ConocoPhillips say that Venezuela owes them billions of dollars for confiscating their assets two decades ago.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A tanker docked near a refinery in Punto Fijo, Venezuela. The cost of restoring the country’s oil production after decades of decline is expected to be substantial.

item.title: After Maduro Ouster, Trump’s Venezuela Moves Pose a Challenge for GOP in Congress
item.description: Republicans have cheered the raid that ousted Nicolás Maduro but toiled to square their longstanding views with President Trump’s unclear and rapidly evolving strategy.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We do not have U.S. armed forces in Venezuela, and we are not occupying that country,” Speaker Mike Johnson said on Monday.

item.title: U.S. Seizes Oil Tanker and Boards Another Amid Tensions With Russia
item.description: The first ship had eluded the Coast Guard after being stopped on its way to pick up oil in Venezuela. U.S. forces also boarded another tanker in international waters near the Caribbean.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Nehamas, Eric Schmitt, Julian E. Barnes and Christiaan Triebert
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Maduro Is Gone, but Repression in Venezuela Has Intensified
item.description: Security forces have boarded buses, searched phones and interrogated people, looking for evidence that they welcomed the capture of Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas

item.title: Europe Tries to Come to Terms With Trump’s Intervention in Venezuela
item.description: Needing U.S. support to fend off Russia in Ukraine, European leaders have been cautious about criticizing President Trump on Greenland, Iran, Venezuela and much else.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: A Ukrainian artillery unit preparing to fire at Russian positions near the frontline city of Pokrovsk in the Donbas region last month.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Nehamas, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes

item.title: Russia Sends Naval Vessel to Escort Oil Tanker U.S. Is Pursuing
item.description: The development deepens the confrontation over the tanker formerly known as the Bella 1, which the United States wants to seize but which Russia has sought to protect.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella, Nicholas Nehamas and Christiaan Triebert
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The oil tanker Marinera, formerly known as Bella 1, at the Singapore Strait in March. Russia has dispatched at least one naval vessel to meet and escort the tanker.

item.title: An emergency order from the Venezuelan government appears to criminalize support for the U.S. attack.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: Nicolás Maduro was escorted off a helicopter on Monday to be taken to the federal court appearance in Manhattan.

item.title: After Trump’s Military Victory in Venezuela, Cuba’s Economy Is in ‘Freefall’
item.description: With widespread power outages, medicine shortages and rising food prices, experts say Cuba’s economy has never been worse, with the crisis coming just as the supply of Venezuelan oil is threatened.
item.dc:creator: David C. Adams and Frances Robles
item.media:description: Cooking soup over an open fire in Havana after the failure of a major power plant in October.

item.title: U.S. Pressures Venezuela to Expel Advisers From Cuba, China, Russia and Iran
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio was said to have listed the Trump administration’s demands to Venezuela’s new leader, Delcy Rodríguez, in a classified meeting Monday with senior congressional leaders.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Edward Wong and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio at the Capitol on Monday. He spoke at a classified meeting with senior congressional leaders.

item.title: Latin American countries condemn the U.S. at the Organization of American States meeting.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:description: Albert Ramdin, secretary general of the Organization of American States, speaking at an emergency meeting in Washington, on Tuesday.

item.title: The Trump administration covets Venezuela’s oil reserves, and the implications for the planet could be serious.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Venezuela has about 17 percent of the world’s known oil reserves.

item.title: The Players to Know in Venezuela’s Leadership
item.description: Since President Trump deposed Nicolás Maduro, his entrenched web of loyalists has appeared to remain intact. Here’s a look at some of the most influential.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Delcy Rodríguez, Venezuela’s vice president, was sworn in as interim leader on Monday.

item.title: 2 Caribbean Nations Agree to Host People Seeking Asylum in U.S.
item.description: The island nations of Dominica, and Antigua and Barbuda, recently targeted by Washington, said they had reached deals to receive asylum seekers turned away by the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: Prime minister Gaston Browne of Antigua and Barbuda addressing the United Nations General Assembly in New York in September.

item.title: Europe Rallies for Greenland as Trump’s Threats Continue
item.description: The show of solidarity comes as President Trump, emboldened by his capture of Nicolás Maduro from Venezuela, has suggested he could take action against other countries.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, right, greeting Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen of Denmark before a summit of European leaders at the Élysée Palace in Paris on Tuesday.

item.title: After Maduro’s Ouster, Marco Rubio Faces the Challenge of Running Venezuela
item.description: The secretary of state helped steer President Trump to attacking Venezuela and seizing Nicolás Maduro, and now aims to force the country to give U.S. companies access to its oil.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: A poor outcome in Venezuela could jeopardize Secretary of State Marco Rubio’s chances at higher office.

item.title: Maduro Invokes Prisoner-of-War Status, Echoing Panama’s Noriega
item.description: The argument worked for Manuel Antonio Noriega, who wore a uniform at trial and received special P.O.W. privileges after his conviction.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.media:description: Supporters of President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela demonstrating in Caracas, Venezuela, on Sunday. Mr. Maduro was seized by U.S. forces on Saturday.

item.title: Trump Claims Venezuela Will Send U.S. Millions of Barrels of Oil. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: It is unclear what, if anything, Venezuela would get in return for the oil, which is worth somewhere between $1.8 billion and $3 billion at current market prices.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed and Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: An oil refinery in Punto Fijo, Venezuela. In November, the country’s oil production was estimated at 820,000 barrels a day.

item.title: Can Venezuela’s New Leader Keep the U.S. Happy and Her Elites in Line?
item.description: As the country’s status quo abruptly shifts, experts say maintaining a coalition is crucial for political survival.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Delcy Rodríguez moments before being sworn in as Venezuela’s president in Caracas, on Monday.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Daniel Victor

item.title: Maduro’s Gesture Was Not Just a Peace Sign
item.description: The captured authoritarian leader flashed a symbol that many took to be a defiant peace sign. Loyal lawmakers repeated the gesture at a session in Caracas.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.media:description: Venezuela’s leader, Nicolás Maduro, arriving in New York, on Saturday.

item.title: Venezuela’s Machado Praises Trump in Fox News Interview
item.description: María Corina Machado, the Venezuelan opposition leader, offered to share her Nobel Peace Prize with President Trump. He has refused to back her.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: María Corina Machado at a rally during the country’s presidential election in 2024.
